Content: A student sets up the cardboard tube shown. The student holds the tube at an angle. The student drops a ball into each hole, then measures how fast the ball travels when it comes out of the tube.
problems/TN20G4S/media/1a.jpg
Dropping the ball into which hole will cause the ball to travel the fastest?

A.Choice: Hole 1, because the ball will have the most potential energy

B.Choice: Hole 2, because the ball will have the most kinetic energy

C.Choice: Hole 3, because the ball will have the least potential energy

D.Choice: Hole 4, because the ball will have the least kinetic energy

Content: A student struck the bars shown on this xylophone. The student used the same amount of force to strike each bar. Each note that the student played had the same volume.
problems/TN20G4S/media/2a.jpg
Each time the student struck the xylophone, a machine recorded the wave as an image. The picture shows the wave image recorded when the student struck bar 1 on the xylophone.
problems/TN20G4S/media/2b.jpg
Which picture shows the m͟o͟s͟t͟ ͟l͟i͟k͟e͟l͟y wave image recorded when the student struck bar 2 on the xylophone?
The graph shows population growth and water usage for the world.
problems/TN20G4S/media/3a.jpg
Which statement is c͟o͟r͟r͟e͟c͟t based on the data shown?

A.Choice: The amount of water used is not related to the human population.

B.Choice: The amount of water used is higher when the human population is lower.

C.Choice: The amount of water used is lowest when the human population is highest.

D.Choice: The amount of water used is higher when the human population is higher.

Content: Which t͟h͟r͟e͟e statements correctly describe materials plants need?

S.Choice: Plants need carbon dioxide to photosynthesize.

Content: The table shows typical temperatures in a gray wolf habitat.
problems/TN20G4S/media/5a.jpg
Which of these b͟e͟s͟t describes a way that gray wolves adapt to survive the changing temperatures?

A.Choice: Wolves develop a heavy coat in the fall and shed it in the spring.

B.Choice: Each wolf’s howl sounds different from the others.

C.Choice: A wolf pack works together to find food in the fall.

D.Choice: Wolves are most active at sunrise and sunset.

Content: Students took turns rolling a ball across a classroom floor. A sensor measured the speed of the ball at the one-meter mark. The students recorded the speed in a data table.
problems/TN20G4S/media/6a.jpg
Which conclusion is supported by the data?

M.Choice: The ball had the most energy on roll 1.

P.Choice: The ball had the least energy on roll 4.

R.Choice: The ball had less energy on roll 1 than on roll 2.

S.Choice: The ball had more energy on roll 2 than on roll 3.

Content: A science quote from an article about land use is shown.
:box:“Science studies show that when people build more roads, parking lots, sidewalks, and rooftops, there is more storm water runoff. This can cause more flooding and erosion.”
Which human activity is the author talking about in the quote?
The diagram shown is a model of the different layers inside Earth.
problems/TN20G4S/media/8a.jpg
Which t͟w͟o statements b͟e͟s͟t compare the crust to the rest of the layers?

M.Choice: The crust surrounds all the other layers and is solid.

P.Choice: The crust is the innermost layer and is liquid.

R.Choice: The crust is the thinnest layer and is solid.

S.Choice: The crust is the outermost layer and is liquid.

T.Choice: The crust is the thickest layer and is solid.

Content: A simplified food web of a marsh ecosystem is shown.
problems/TN20G4S/media/9a.jpg
Which organisms get energy from crickets?
The diagram shows a V-shaped valley. The valley did not exist thousands of years ago.
problems/TN20G4S/media/10a.jpg
This valley is m͟o͟s͟t͟ ͟l͟i͟k͟e͟l͟y the result of

M.Choice: sediment being deposited by slow-moving water.

P.Choice: riverbanks being eroded by fast-moving water.

R.Choice: earthquakes causing the ground to split open.

S.Choice: glaciers moving sediment to a new location.

Content: A beaver is a mammal that builds its home in a stream or river. The beaver’s home is called a lodge. The beaver builds the lodge in the middle of a pond it creates by building dams in the stream. The picture shows a model of a stream ecosystem with two beaver dams and a beaver lodge.
problems/TN20G4S/media/11a.jpg
Based on the model, what would m͟o͟s͟t͟ ͟l͟i͟k͟e͟l͟y happen to the ecosystem if the beavers and their dams were removed?

A.Choice: The trees would have more water to use as the stream water moves more slowly through the ecosystem.

B.Choice: The stream would be wider and deeper as the stream water moves more slowly through the ecosystem.

C.Choice: The banks of the stream would have less erosion as the stream water moves more quickly through the ecosystem.

D.Choice: The water used by plants on the banks of the stream would be reduced as the stream water moves more quickly through the ecosystem.

Content: A student saw a rainbow outside after school. The next day the student decided to model how rainbows form. The student shines white light through a glass prism and sees how the light splits up into many colors.
problems/TN20G4S/media/12a.jpg
problems/TN20G4S/media/12b.jpg
Which t͟w͟o ways does the student’s model need to be changed to better show how rainbows are formed?

M.Choice: The prism should be as high in the air as rainbows are.

P.Choice: The model needs to be outside because rainbows only form outside.

R.Choice: The prism should have a round shape because raindrops are round.

S.Choice: The prism should be made of water instead of glass because rain is made of water.

T.Choice: Sunlight should be used instead of white light because sunlight and white light are made of different things.

Content: On a forest field trip, a student is assigned a list of observations to make. One observation the student looks for is evidence of mechanical weathering.
Which activity would allow the student to check mechanical weathering off the list?

A.Choice: an acorn falling out of a tree

B.Choice: an ant placing a soil particle on an anthill

C.Choice: a puddle getting smaller as the sun shines on it

D.Choice: a stone becoming smooth in a flowing riverbed

Content: A student labeled two locations on a map as shown.
problems/TN20G4S/media/14a.jpg
The student claims locations 1 and 2 may experience sunset at the same time. Which statement provides evidence for this argument?

M.Choice: Both locations are on the same line of longitude.

P.Choice: Both locations are on the same line of latitude.

R.Choice: Both locations are in the Eastern Hemisphere.

S.Choice: Both locations are on the same continent.

Content: A student states that plants need sunlight to grow. The student plans an investigation to help support the argument with evidence. The diagrams represent four different setups.
Which setup will give the m͟o͟s͟t evidence to support the student’s claim?
The table shows information about some energy resources.
problems/TN20G4S/media/16a.jpg
After observing the table, students conclude that renewable resources of energy should be used more to have cleaner air.
Which t͟h͟r͟e͟e explanations support this conclusion?

M.Choice: More wind energy produced means more pollution.

P.Choice: Natural gas is a fossil fuel that must be removed from under the ground.

R.Choice: The largest amount of electricity is produced from nonrenewable resources.

S.Choice: Getting coal from beneath Earth’s surface destroys the ecosystem in that location.

T.Choice: Solar cells absorb energy that would normally be used by plants to make oxygen.

Content: Many objects produce thermal energy.
problems/TN20G4S/media/17a.jpg
problems/TN20G4S/media/17a.jpg
Students want to sort the objects into two groups.

:box:• Group 1: Objects that use electricity to produce thermal energy

• Group 2: Objects that use stored energy to produce thermal energy
Which question should the students ask to decide which object to put into Group 2?

A.Choice: How much thermal energy does the object produce?

B.Choice: How do people use the thermal energy produced by the object?

C.Choice: Can the object produce thermal energy without being plugged in?

D.Choice: Can the thermal energy produced by the object be changed into another form of energy?

Content: An area with many different types of plants is experiencing a drought. The table shows rainfall for four years.
problems/TN20G4S/media/18a.jpg
Scientists predict that the rainfall pattern will continue during a fifth year. Which two types of plants will have the b͟e͟s͟t chance of surviving in these conditions?

M.Choice: plants with stems that store water and plants with large colorful flowers

P.Choice: plants with large colorful flowers and plants with sharp thorns

R.Choice: plants with sharp thorns and plants with long root systems

S.Choice: plants with long root systems and plants with stems that store water

Content: The map on the left shows the Andes mountain range in South America. The map on the right shows the Himalayan mountain range in India.
problems/TN20G4S/media/19a.jpg
problems/TN20G4S/media/19b.jpg
The mountain ranges in these maps are evidence that mountain ranges

A.Choice: form at the border of two tectonic plates.

B.Choice: form in the middle of a tectonic plate.

C.Choice: exist on their own separate tectonic plates.

D.Choice: represent the formation of new tectonic plates.

Content: Students classified organisms based on their roles in a forest ecosystem. The data table shows how the students classified the organisms of a forest ecosystem.
problems/TN20G4S/media/20a.jpg
Which t͟w͟o energy flows are c͟o͟r͟r͟e͟c͟t based on the students’ classifications?
Scientists found layers of rock containing the fossils shown.
problems/TN20G4S/media/21a.jpg
Which conclusion can scientists make from studying these rock layers?
A photograph of a river delta is shown.
problems/TN20G4S/media/22a.jpg
Which statement correctly describes the delta in the photograph?

M.Choice: Deposition is causing the delta to become narrower over time.

P.Choice: Deposition is causing the delta to become bigger over time.

R.Choice: Erosion is causing the delta to become smaller over time.

S.Choice: Erosion is causing the delta to become wider over time.

Content: Some animals protect coral reefs while others harm them. The Crown of Thorns Starfish came to a certain coral reef in the Pacific Ocean in 2015. The graph shows the size of the reef over time.
problems/TN20G4S/media/23a.jpg
Which statement about the size of the reef is supported by the data in the graph?

A.Choice: The number of starfish in the area dropped after 2015.

B.Choice: The starfish made the coral reef smaller from 2015 to 2018.

C.Choice: The coral reef was healthy and growing from 2013 to 2018.

D.Choice: The coral reef lost more than 2,000 meters from 2015 to 2018.

Content: Students dropped a ball of dough from different heights and timed how long it took the ball to fall to the floor. They then drew the shape of the dough after it hit the floor. Their data are in the table.
problems/TN20G4S/media/24a.jpg
Based on the data collected, which t͟w͟o conclusions can students make about the speed and energy of the dough when it hit the floor?

M.Choice: The dough had the fastest speed and the least kinetic energy when dropped from a height of 1 meter.

P.Choice: The dough had the slowest speed and the most kinetic energy when dropped from a height of 1 meter.

R.Choice: The dough had more speed and kinetic energy when dropped from a height of 2 meters than from 1 meter.

S.Choice: The dough had less speed and kinetic energy when dropped from a height of 4 meters than from 3 meters.

T.Choice: The dough had the fastest speed and the most kinetic energy when dropped from a height of 5 meters.

Content: The food web shown is from an area in Tennessee.
problems/TN20G4S/media/25a.jpg
Which organisms are decomposers that should be added to complete the food web?

Two friends live near each other. Friend 1 calls Friend 2. Friend 1 talks into the cell phone. The cell phone changes the sound of Friend 1’s voice into digital information. The digital information goes to the nearest radio tower as radio waves. The radio tower sends those radio waves to Friend 2’s cell phone. Friend 2’s cell phone changes the radio waves back into digital information. The digital information is then turned into sound so that Friend 2 can hear Friend 1.
problems/TN20G4S/media/26a.jpg
Why are Friend 1’s sounds turned into digital information?

M.Choice: in case people do not speak clearly

P.Choice: so the sounds can be sent as radio waves

R.Choice: so Friend 2 can communicate with the tower

S.Choice: in case the radio waves do not reach Friend 2’s cell phone

Content: Students choose playground activities to demonstrate energy transfer.
Which activity shows a transfer of potential energy to kinetic energy?

A.Choice: sliding from the top of a slide

Content: Shadows of objects on Earth change throughout the day. This occurs because Earth rotates.
Which t͟w͟o models show how the sun causes shadows to appear on Earth?
The graph shows the thickness of Earth’s layers.
problems/TN20G4S/media/29a.jpg
Which table correctly identifies Earth’s layers from thinnest to thickest?
A food chain is shown.
problems/TN20G4S/media/30a.jpg
The energy that the organisms in this food chain use for growth began as energy from the
